stimulusHtml:
Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A belt capable of transporting electric charge is connected by a motor to a spherical conducting surface of radius R. The motor and conducting surface are separated by an insulating stand. When the motor is turned on for a time t, an unknown amount of charge Q0 is transferred onto the sphere. After the sphere has been charged, an uncharged conducting ball of radius r hanging from a nonconducting string is brought close to, but not touching, the sphere. The sphere and ball then touch, and a short time later the ball hangs at an angle Î¸ relative to the vertical. The height of the ball is adjusted such that the center of the ball and the sphere are at the same vertical height, as shown. The students measure the radii of the sphere and ball and determine that R=10r and correctly conclude that after the ball and sphere touch, the charge remaining on the conducting sphere Q and the charge on the ball q are related by the expression Q=10q. The rate S at which charge is transferred onto the sphere when the motor is turned on is approximately constant for 8 seconds of charging. The students are expected to experimentally determine S by plotting their data in a graph. The students have access to equipment typically found in a high school physics lab.

(a) Clearly identify each quantity to be measured, the symbol used to represent that quantity, and the equipment that would be used to measure the quantity.

(b) Briefly describe the procedure a student would use to gather data that would be used to determine the rate S at which charge is transferred onto the sphere. Provide enough detail so that another student could replicate the experiment, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty. As needed, use the symbols defined in part (a).
(c) Which quantities (raw data or calculated from the data) would be graphed on the vertical and horizontal axes to produce a linear graph that could be used to determine S ?
(d) Describe which information from the graph described in part (c) would be used and how it would be used to determine S.

(e) A student argues that the induced charge separation on both the sphere and ball has affected their results. Would an induced separation of charge on the sphere and ball result in a calculation of S that is greater than, less than, or equal to the actual value of S ? Justify your answer.
